pageProps.body:
Taylor Series

Suppose a function fff has the derivatives f(k)(a)f^{(k)}(a)f(k)(a) of all orders at the point aaa. If we write the Taylor polynomial of a degree nnn for fff centered at aaa and allow nnn to increase indefinitely, a power series is obtained:

c0+c1(x−a)+c2(x−a)n+⋯+cn(x−a)n+⋯=∑k=0∞ck(x−a)k.c_0+c_1(x-a)+c_2(x-a)^n+\cdots+c_n(x-a)^n+\cdots=\sum_{k=0}^\infty c_k(x-a)^k\text.c0​+c1​(x−a)+c2​(x−a)n+⋯+cn​(x−a)n+⋯=k=0∑∞​ck​(x−a)k.

The coefficients of the Taylor polynomial are given by

ck=f(k)(a)k!, for k=0,1,2,….c_k=\frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k!}\text{, for }k=0,1,2,\dots\text.ck​=k!f(k)(a)​, for k=0,1,2,….

These coefficients are also the coefficients of the power series, which is called the "Taylor series for fff centered at aaa". The special case of a Taylor series centered at 000 is called a Maclaurin series.

Definition

Suppose the function fff has the derivatives of all orders on an interval centered at the point aaa. The Taylor series for fff centered at aaa is

T∞=f(a)+f′(a)(x−a)+f′′(a)2!(x−a)2+f(3)(a)3!(x−a)3+⋯=∑k=0∞f(k)(a)k!(x−a)k.T_\infty=f(a)+f\prime(a)(x-a)+\frac{f\prime\prime(a)}{2!}(x-a)^2+\frac{f^{(3)}(a)}{3!}(x-a)^3+\cdots=\sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{f^{(k)}(a)}{k!}(x-a)^k\text.T∞​=f(a)+f′(a)(x−a)+2!f′′(a)​(x−a)2+3!f(3)(a)​(x−a)3+⋯=k=0∑∞​k!f(k)(a)​(x−a)k.

To clarify, xxx is not the point at which the Taylor series is centered. Rather, xxx is the variable to be used in the resulting function Tn(x)≈f(x)T_n(x)\approx f(x)Tn​(x)≈f(x). aaa is the point at which the Taylor series is centered.

A Taylor series centered at 000 is called a Maclaurin series.
